structured_info.title_cn: 车道政策对混合手动和联网自动驾驶车辆的高速公路交通影响
structured_info.title_en: Influence of Lane Policies on Freeway Traffic Mixed with Manual and Connected and Autonomous Vehicles
structured_info.abstract: Connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) have become the highlights of traffic. Researchers in this field have proposed various traffic management measures to enhance the capacity and efficiency of traffic with CAVs, especially mixed traffic of CAVs and manual vehicles (MVs). Exclusive lane setting is included. However, exclusive lane policy-related researches for mixed traffic of CAVs and MVs were very limited, and the influence of number and location of exclusive lanes on the mixed traffic was unclear. To fill this gap, this paper aims to study the influence of different exclusive lane policies on mixed traffic and provide recommended lane policies under various traffic volumes and CAV penetration rates. Freeways with two lanes and three lanes in a single direction were taken into consideration, and sixteen lane policies were proposed. Then different lane policies were simulated with a new proposed cellular automata (CA) model, and properties including flux, average speed, and CAVs degradation were analyzed to evaluate the traffic efficiency of each lane policy. The results show that CAV exclusive lanes can improve the capacity, while MV exclusive lanes seem helpless for capacity improvement. Seven lane policies, including GC, GM, and CM for two-lane freeways and GCG, CGC, and CCM for three-lane freeways, outperform the others in terms of average speed. In addition, exclusive lanes can reduce the probability that CAVs degenerate to AVs. Our findings may help to optimize freeways' lane policies and improve the efficiency of heterogeneous traffic mixed with CAVs and MVs.
structured_info.methodology: The study uses a cellular automata (CA) model to simulate mixed traffic of CAVs and MVs under various lane policies. The model incorporates car-following and lane-changing behaviors for both vehicle types. Sixteen lane policies are evaluated based on traffic flux, average speed, and CAV degradation rates.
structured_info.conclusion: CAV exclusive lanes improve traffic capacity, especially at higher CAV penetration rates, while MV exclusive lanes do not. Recommended lane policies for optimal average speed are GC, GM, and CM for two-lane freeways and GCG, CGC, and CCM for three-lane freeways. Exclusive lanes also reduce CAV degradation to AVs.

analysis.Overview: The paper investigates the impact of different lane policies on mixed traffic involving manual vehicles (MVs) and connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) using a cellular automata model. It evaluates traffic efficiency metrics like capacity, average speed, and CAV degradation under various policies.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the challenges of integrating CAVs into existing traffic systems, focusing on the interaction between CAVs and MVs.
The motivation is to optimize lane policies to enhance traffic efficiency and capacity in mixed traffic scenarios.
The authors highlight the lack of research on exclusive lane policies for mixed CAV and MV traffic, emphasizing the need for such studies.
The problem is significant as mixed traffic will persist for a long time, impacting traffic operations and safety.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering and intelligent transportation systems (ITS).
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include CAVs, MVs, exclusive lanes (CAV, MV, general purpose), and traffic efficiency metrics.
The logical relationship involves how lane policies affect traffic flow dynamics and vehicle interactions.
Key assumptions include the behavior models for CAVs and MVs and the simulation parameters.
The paper contributes empirical insights into optimal lane policies for mixed traffic, advancing knowledge in traffic management.
Methodology: The core method is a cellular automata model simulating mixed traffic under various lane policies.
The novelty lies in the comprehensive evaluation of multiple lane policies and their impact on traffic metrics.
Data sources are simulation-based, with parameters calibrated from real traffic data where available.
Experimental design includes varying CAV penetration rates and traffic densities to assess policy performance.
The research follows a simulation-based paradigm, common in traffic flow studies.
Results: Key results show that CAV exclusive lanes improve capacity, especially at higher CAV penetration rates, while MV exclusive lanes do not.
The results are reliable as they are based on multiple simulation runs and averaged outcomes.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The argument structure starts with problem identification, literature review, methodology, results, and conclusions.
Key steps include defining lane policies, simulating traffic, and analyzing performance metrics.
Strengths include comprehensive policy evaluation; weaknesses may include simplified assumptions in the CA model.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Detailed simulation of multiple lane policies, clear recommendations for optimal policies.
Limitations: Simplified vehicle behavior models, lack of real-world validation.
Theoretical constraints include the assumption of perfect CAV communication and behavior.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper positions itself within traffic management and ITS discourse, citing relevant literature.
Terminology includes technical terms like CAVs, MVs, and cellular automata.
Citations build authority by referencing prior work in CAV and traffic simulation.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Conclusions highlight the benefits of CAV exclusive lanes and recommend specific policies for different scenarios.
Future research could explore more complex traffic scenarios and real-world implementations.
